value.title: How SaaS startup Credgenics is helping banks, NBFCs, and fintechs recover their bad debts through AI/ML
value.excerpt: Credgenics is an end-to-end, SaaS-based, collection management tool, which delivers customised strategies and recommends optimal legal routes to facilitate faster resolution of stressed assets.

value.title: Ai-Da, the first robot artist to be exhibiting herself
value.excerpt: The robot was named Ai-Da after the 19th century mathematician Ada Lovelace. According to its creators, it is capable of drawing real people using its camera eye and a pencil in hand. She 'looks' in the mirror that is integrated with her camera eyes and with the help of algorithm programs transforms it into coordinates.

value.title: IBM’s hybrid cloud strategy is gaining steam
value.excerpt: IBM is quietly acquiring capabilities and establishing partnerships that may make it the number one provider of hybrid cloud solutions.

value.title: This AI-powered gadget could completely disrupt the ridiculous hearing aid market
value.excerpt: Hearing loss sucks. It’s exhausting. I’ve suffered from partial hearing loss in both ears since the mid 2000’s. In order to function in the real world, I’m forced to exist in a state of constant vigilance.

value.title: Chip mavens of the ISSCC gather virtually for AI, quantum, 5G

value.title: Humana (HUM) Joins IBM Watson Health to Aid Member Experience
value.excerpt: Humana Inc. HUM recently tied up with IBM Watson Health through which it can serve its members better through the latter’s conversational AI solution. The partnership is expected to provide more transparency on benefits to the Humana Employer Group members.

value.title: This ‘AI doctor’ can assess skin melanoma as accurately as human dermatologists

value.title: Pediatric brain tumors can be classified using diffusion weighted imaging and machine learning
value.excerpt: Diffusion weighted imaging and machine learning can successfully classify the diagnosis and characteristics of common types of pediatric brain tumors a UK-based multi-center study, including WMG at the University of Warwick has found.

value.title: Russian police use facial recognition or ‘face control’ against protesters
value.excerpt: He was detained on his way there by police using facial recognition technology in the Moscow metro. But reports from other protesters who have attend rallies in recent weeks in support of jailed opposition politician Alexei Navalny also indicate police are using facial recognition technology to make preventive arrests and detentions.
